{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3641018,"name":"Alexander Carlisi","username":"AlexanderCarlisi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alexandercarlisi/{size}/255089_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T16:50:05.335Z","cooked":"

Help us settle a debate please.

My teammate has proposed the question, that if it would be better to have the Elevator in Coast mode and only rely on PID to hold to elevator to a position, as opposed to only relying on Brake mode to hold the elevator in position. (Currently brake mode is able to hold the elevator in position on its own). His idea is that brake mode uses a constant arbitrary power that the manufacturers set to the motor to hold it in place, as opposed to the kG constant which will be tuned to the elevator. Saying that Back-EMF only supplies a dampening force, so there must be some other function holding position. Saying that both Back-EMF and kG couldn’t possibly be running at the same time.

I’m of the opinion that Brake mode wouldn’t be a constant power since that just conceptually doesn’t make sense to me, and that the dampening force of Back-EMF would also dampen Gravity’s effect on the elevator. Brake mode should be providing a Passive resistance to the forces, so it shouldn’t be consuming more power than coast.

To be completely specific as to what we’re working with. It’s an elevator with two Kraken x60 motors.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T16:50:30.220Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":20,"reads":415,"readers_count":414,"score":198.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Alexander Carlisi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62389,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641028,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T17:01:08.140Z","cooked":"
AlexanderCarlisi:

His idea is that brake mode uses a constant arbitrary power that the manufacturers set to the motor to hold it in place

This is not how brake mode works.

AlexanderCarlisi:

the dampening force of Back-EMF would also dampen Gravity’s effect on the elevator

When power is not being applied, yes. Elevators in coast mode will crash down rather violently when power is cut. During dynamic operation it shouldn’t have an effect.

The difference in power consumption between coast and brake mode is going to be negligible.

Generally, we keep any system that is under closed loop control in brake mode. Even if two X60s under brake mode can hold your elevator up, you want a properly tuned kG value for feedforward control anyway, so might as well just let the loop keep the elevator in the right spot.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T17:02:25.096Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":378,"readers_count":377,"score":180.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Rahul Yarlagadda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641036,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T17:11:08.509Z","cooked":"
AlexanderCarlisi:

His idea is that brake mode uses a constant arbitrary power that the manufacturers set to the motor to hold it in place, as opposed to the kG constant which will be tuned to the elevator. Saying that Back-EMF only supplies a dampening force, so there must be some other function holding position. Saying that both Back-EMF and kG couldn’t possibly be running at the same time.

Brake/coast only has an effect when the requested motor output duty cycle/voltage/torque current is exactly 0; they do not take effect with a constant non-zero kG output.

In brake mode, the motor leads are essentially shorted together. That makes it so back emf (velocity / K_v) is fed back into the motor, so the braking force is directly proportional to the velocity of the system. There is no additional driving force.

By comparison, in coast mode, the motor is left an open circuit, so at 0 output the elevator will just freefall.

Most notably, brake mode is equivalent to 0 V output, or 0% duty cycle output, whereas coast mode is equivalent to 0 A output. If you are using voltage or duty cycle control, brake mode maintains continuity of behavior at all voltage/duty cycle requests. On the other hand, if you are using TorqueCurrentFOC control, coast mode maintains continuity of behavior.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T17:11:08.509Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":346,"readers_count":345,"score":234.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Benjamin Hall","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48146,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641153,"name":"Alexander Carlisi","username":"AlexanderCarlisi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alexandercarlisi/{size}/255089_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T19:42:47.932Z","cooked":"

His response to @bhall-ctre and @Knufire

In a horizontal plane there would be no additional driving force, but and a vertical plane such an elevator there would be the additional driving force of gravity.

Because back EMF is directly proportional to the velocity. The back EMF would have to produce more force than gravity is exerting on it. in a closed system without any additional power, this would violate the first laws of thermodynamics.

There must be a counteractive force for gravity. This force would have to be in the motor driving against gravity. I have observed this when our elevator is being held up in break mode there is still a power draw on the motors.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T19:42:47.932Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":32,"reads":259,"readers_count":258,"score":221.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Alexander Carlisi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62389,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/4","reactions":[{"id":"question","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641157,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T19:48:03.795Z","cooked":"
AlexanderCarlisi:

I have observed this when our elevator is being held up in break mode there is still a power draw on the motors.

If there’s a power draw from the battery there is no way the mechanism is in brake mode.

Motion in brake mode pushes current back into the battery. Brake mode is the same as using the motor as a generator.

A mechanism in brake mode may stay still, but this is due to friction, not the brake mode force. Viscous drag cannot (alone) hold anything still.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T19:49:31.221Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":234,"readers_count":233,"score":66.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641160,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T19:56:40.866Z","cooked":"

Since a motor in brake mode push current into a battery, could you charge your battery on the fly by rotating a motor in brake mode?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T19:56:40.866Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":206,"readers_count":205,"score":61.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/6","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641161,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T19:58:10.293Z","cooked":"

Yes.

You can also damage your electronics by over-volting them, especially if you force it backwards through a large gear reduction.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T19:58:10.293Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":197,"readers_count":196,"score":89.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":62698,"username":"CakeDeer6","name":"Ethan Grieshop","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641162,"name":"Karl Olson","username":"olsonkarlp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/b9bd4f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T19:58:14.167Z","cooked":"

Yes. Simply speaking, a motor is a generator in reverse.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T19:58:14.167Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":192,"readers_count":191,"score":83.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Karl Olson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":62698,"username":"CakeDeer6","name":"Ethan Grieshop","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36434,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Technical Mentor | 3476"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641168,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T20:02:38.947Z","cooked":"

Yes, sort of. This is how regenerative braking works.

But you’re not able to drive the motor and generate power (backdrive) at the same time. Switching between those modes very carefully is how stuff like this happens. For normal motors, there’s extra protection to manage where the extra power goes when you do things like stop or reverse output.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T20:02:38.947Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":196,"readers_count":195,"score":39.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":62698,"username":"CakeDeer6","name":"Ethan Grieshop","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/9","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641175,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T20:10:27.026Z","cooked":"
AlexanderCarlisi:

The back EMF would have to produce more force than gravity is exerting on it. in a closed system without any additional power, this would violate the first laws of thermodynamics.

There must be a counteractive force for gravity. This force would have to be in the motor driving against gravity.

Well, I work at one of the vendors developing these motor controllers, and I’ve worked on some of the firmware for these motor controllers (such as the Talon FXS). We do not actively drive the motor to 0 velocity when braking. That would require position or velocity PID on the user side.

There does not necessarily need to be a counteractive force coming from the motor. If your gearing is high enough and the elevator is completely stationary, even coast mode may hold the elevator up—static friction is doing all the work. Meanwhile, if the elevator is falling even slightly, then back emf combined with friction is preventing the system from accelerating further. Keep in mind that the torque output from back emf braking is scaled up by the gear ratio just like regular motor output.

AlexanderCarlisi:

I have observed this when our elevator is being held up in break mode there is still a power draw on the motors.

There will be stator current in the motor, although it should be negative to indicate braking. There should not be any reported supply current, since motor output is 0.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T20:13:01.850Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":278.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Benjamin Hall","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48146,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":11},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641189,"name":"Zach Hoegberg","username":"Zaque","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zaque/{size}/257827_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T20:41:55.066Z","cooked":"
AlexanderCarlisi:

Saying that both Back-EMF and kG couldn’t possibly be running at the same time.

This is true. As several others have pointed out, brake mode only actually takes effect when the motor controller is in neutral, i.e. receives a command of 0. Has your teammate verified via the status lights that the motor is actually in neutral (solid orange) and not receiving a small command (slowly blinking red or green) due to a feedforward term? That would also explain the current draw they claimed to see (assuming it was supply current and not stator current as discussed above). If it is truly in neutral, then the elevator is being held up by a combination of friction and braking power amplified by whatever gear ratio you have.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T20:41:55.066Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":173,"readers_count":172,"score":44.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Zach Hoegberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/hardware-reference/talonfx/index.html#status-light-reference","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Talon FX","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20681,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"112 Drive Coach | 111&112 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/11","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641190,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/8072_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T20:44:50.834Z","cooked":"
CakeDeer6:

could you charge your battery on the fly by rotating a motor in brake mode?

Indeed, that is a thing.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T20:44:50.834Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":167,"readers_count":166,"score":43.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regenerative_braking","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Regenerative braking - Wikipedia","clicks":37}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/12","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641204,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T21:07:18.604Z","cooked":"

Though, notably, you always pair it with a physical brake because (as has been discussed here) it does nothing near zero speed so it won’t actually stop you except asymptotically.

His response:
So assuming your elevator is built well with little friction. brake mode would not work to hold it in place and you would have to use PID with kG FF.

OK, now I’m confused, because my mental model of “brake mode” was “short the phases and disconnect the power”, but I realize now that I think three half-bridges can’t do that. What are the output devices actually doing in brake mode?

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T21:15:13.852Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":149,"readers_count":148,"score":54.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/15","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641216,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T21:37:53.616Z","cooked":"

It depends on the gear reduction and your load. More reduction = more resisting torque generated for the same velocity, opposing the load.

We had 2 X60s geared effectively 3:1 (6:1 on a 2-stage cascade) on a ~1.75" spool diameter with a ~12lb carriage and and the elevator would slowly descend (maybe 1-2in/s) under brake mode with no power.

I would like to emphasize that this debate started because we noticed that others teams elevators would play the Stall Whistle when at a Setpoint, as opposed to ours not making any sound.

In which case we were both wondering if it should be making that sound, and if not then whats going on with that.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T21:39:23.677Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":33.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Alexander Carlisi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62389,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/17","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641221,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T21:42:40.473Z","cooked":"

That is separate from brake/coast entirely. The stall whistle takes effect when the motor is stalled (no motion) and is outputting at least ~5% duty cycle. Teams that are getting the stall whistle simply have a larger kG holding their elevator up (which means they’re likely running a lower gear reduction).

bhall-ctre:

The stall whistle takes effect when the motor is stalled (no motion) and is outputting at least ~5% duty cycle.

Is this documented anywhere? It’d be great to know how this functions in more detail (e.g. what constitutes “no motion,” different volumes of the stall whistle, etc.)

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T21:48:46.930Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":141,"readers_count":140,"score":138.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502595,"topic_slug":"elevators-and-brake-mode","display_username":"Eugene Fang","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":"The-Blue-Alliance","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/0/2/02b18ea7720fea44e77469bb5261acf1c7045a6e.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":67,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7439,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"604 Alum & Mentor | The Blue Alliance"},"post_url":"/t/elevators-and-brake-mode/502595/19","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3641226,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T21:57:20.712Z","cooked":"

In general, with typical gearing, mass, and friction of an elevator, brake mode would not hold it up. Brake mode would provide velocity-proportional force so the elevator would not crash down to a physical stop when zero volts is being applied to the motors. The rate of descent would be less than “crash” rate and could be quite slow depending on the listed factors above. Accurate feedforward would be sufficient to hold it up. Feedback is not necessarily required, but if it is active, it will compensate for inaccuracy in feedforward to ensure that the elevator neither descends nor rises when the height is at setpoint.
